metadata.case_name: Suleman Issa v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Appellant Suleman Issa, inhabitant of Natal in South Africa, left Durban in August 1947 by car for India to visit native place Sarsa in District Kaira, accompanied by Daud Hassam.
Travelled to Mombasa by car, took boat on August 30 to Colombo on September 11, flew to Madras on September 14, car shipped by steamer, arrived Madras end September.
In Madras, paid Rs. 2,700 custom duty and Rs. 10,000 cash deposit as security for car intended to take back to Durban; car delivered October 1.
Motored to Nardana on October 7 via Bangalore, Poona, Nasik, Dhulia; then train to Sarsa on October 8; car booked from Nardana to Anand, then driven to Sarsa.
Ratansing Kalusing Raol, Senior Police Inspector Nadiad, noticed car with Indian number, instructed watch; appellant ordered to appear before Sub-Inspector October 12.
Appellant stated family original inhabitants of Jamnagar State, business in Durban for 60 years; Daud Issa serving in Bombay; gave journey details, produced passports, custom receipts.

October 15, Head Constable Ajit Singh informed Raol of unknown person with gold at Umarbhai jeweller; police seized gold given by appellant to melt, plus other gold; total 27731 tolas worth Rs. 3 lakhs.

Police took possession of car; proceedings under s.20 Indian Telegraph Act dropped as wireless not transmitter; car examined, nothing incriminating; appellant detained under Public Securities Act, released.
Prosecuted January 2, 1948 on complaint of Raol under s.61E Bombay District Police Act IV of 1890 r/w s.109 IPC.
Sub-Divisional Magistrate Nadiad convicted appellant December 31, 1948, fined Rs.100, confiscated gold u/s 517 CrPC; other accused (abetment) acquitted.
Magistrate: no direct evidence of theft/fraud, but circumstances led to reasonable belief gold stolen or fraudulently obtained.
Sessions Judge Kaira acquitted May 7, 1949: possession suspicious but not sufficient for reasonable belief; set aside conviction, restored gold to appellant.

High Court Bombay (Dixit and Chainani JJ) allowed State appeal June 26, 1950: rejected prosecution story of gold brought in car, but agreed with Magistrate on reasonable belief; rejected appellant's explanation gold from father; restored conviction, confiscation u/s 517.
High Court: s.517 not require offence committed re: property, enough if produced before court.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the court had jurisdiction under section 517 CrPC to confiscate the gold, and whether such confiscation was appropriate in the circumstances.
Whether the gold was produced before the court or regarding which any offence appears to have been committed, for application of s.517 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Concedes conviction under s.61E but s.517 CrPC has no application; gold sent to Treasury, never produced before court.
Even if jurisdiction exists, confiscation not proper order in circumstances.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 517 CrPC; s.61E Bombay District Police Act

respondent_arguments.text: Gold brought into India by appellant in motor-car (High Court rejected but agreed on reasonable belief of stolen/fraudulently obtained).
Rejected appellant's explanation that father brought gold to Sarsa from time to time.
S.517 applicable as property produced before court; no need to find offence committed re: property.

court_reasoning.text: S.517 empowers court on conclusion of inquiry/trial to dispose of property produced before it, in its custody, or re: which offence appears committed or used in offence; includes confiscation but not mandatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power extends to confiscation but not in every case; depends on circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence unclear if gold produced before court (point not raised below); but gold not one re: which offence appears committed or used in offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conviction based on mere belief under s.61E, no proof stolen/fraudulently obtained.

court_reasoning.text: S.61E does not empower confiscation; it's penal under local Police Act, not like Sea Customs Act; max punishment 3 months/ Rs.100 fine; confiscation harsh/unreasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court could deliver to possessor claiming entitlement; no rival claims, gold from appellant's possession.

court_reasoning.text: High Court thought gold smuggled from Africa, but confiscation under s.517 on mere belief under s.61E palpably harsh.

holdings.text: Court has jurisdiction under s.517 to order disposal including confiscation, but must consider circumstances; confiscation not appropriate here.
Order gold delivered to appellant as person entitled to possession.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay District Police Act, IV of 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of possession/conveyance of suspected stolen/fraudulently obtained property without satisfactory account; conviction based on reasonable belief.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Disposal of property produced before court or re: offence; confiscation held inappropriate.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted as containing substantive confiscation penalty, unlike s.61E.

outcome.summary: Appeal conceded on conviction but allowed on confiscation; set aside High Court's order of confiscation under s.517 CrPC as inappropriate; gold to be delivered to appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside confiscation order; gold restored to appellant.

key_quotes.text: "Confiscation is not the only mode of disposal under section 517 and is singularly inappropriate in a case where the accused is prosecuted for an offence punishable with a maximum sentence of 3 months and a fine of Rs. 100."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is not every case in which the court must necessarily pass an order of confiscation irrespective of the circumstances of the case."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "its confiscation under section 517 upon the existence of a mere belief required to sustain a conviction under section 61E was palpably harsh and unreasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
